content.value: Understanding how Linux boots helps users troubleshoot startup issues, manage services, and control what runs automatically. System administrators often need to start, stop, or disable services to improve performance and security.
Why Understanding the Boot Process Is Important

Understanding how Linux boots helps users troubleshoot startup issues, manage services, and control what runs automatically. System administrators often need to start, stop, or disable services to improve performance and security.
Stages of the Linux Boot Process
When a computer is powered on, BIOS or UEFI performs hardware checks and looks for a bootable device such as a hard disk or SSD.
The bootloader loads the Linux kernel into memory. The most common Linux bootloader is GRUB, which also allows users to choose between operating systems.
The kernel is the core of the Linux operating system that manages hardware, memory, and processes.
content.example: Example: The kernel controls CPU usage and device drivers.
